journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Strain enhancement in lead-free Bi0.5(Na0.78K0.22)0.5TiO3 ceramics by CaZrO3 substitution

article-meta.aff: 1Fine Chemicals and Materials Technology Institute, Ulsan Techno Park, Ulsan, Republic of Korea
2School of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Ulsan, Ulsan, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: Jae-Shin Lee, School of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Ulsan, P.O. Box 18, Nam-Ulsan, Ulsan 680-749, Republic of Korea. Email: jslee@ulsan.ac.kr

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue – 6th Annual Energy Harvesting Workshop (EHW), The Hotel Roanoke and Conference Center, Roanoke, Virginia, August 7 – 11, 2011

abstract.p: The effects of CaZrO3 substitution on the crystal structure, electric field–induced strain, and piezoelectric properties of Bi0.5(Na0.78K0.22)0.5TiO3 ceramics have been investigated. The CaZrO3 substitution resulted in a transition from ferroelectric tetragonal to pseudocubic symmetry with relaxor characteristics, leading to degradations in the piezoelectric coupling coefficient, electromechanical quality factor, and piezoelectric coefficient d33. However, the electric field–induced strain was significantly enhanced by the CaZrO3-induced phase transition and reached a highest value of Smax/Emax = 617 pm/V when CaZrO3 content reached 3 mol%. The result supports a prediction that a large strain at the ferroelectric–relaxor transition region can be observed when the tolerance factor of the Bi-perovskite is decreased by the substitution of ABO3-type modifiers.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Lead-free piezoceramics become increasingly important (Rödel et al., 2009; Shrout and Zhang, 2007; Takenaka and Nagata, 2005) because demand for environmentally friendly materials in electronic industry drives search for new alternatives of lead zirconate titanate (PZT)-based ceramics that contain more than 60 wt% harmful Pb. Among various lead-free systems, bismuth sodium titanate Bi0.5Na0.5TiO3 (BNT) ceramics attract great attention, since a giant normalized strain, Smax/Emax, over 500 pm/V under high electric fields was observed in (Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3–BaTiO3–K0.5Na0.5NbO3 (BNT-BT-KNN) ceramics in 2007 (Zhang et al., 2007). Thenceforth, many studies reported enhancements in electric field–induced strain (EFIS) when (1 −x) (Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3–x(Bi0.5K0.5)TiO3 ((1 −x)BNT-xBKT or Bi0.5(Na0.78K0.22)0.5TiO3 (BNKT)) solid solutions near morphotropic phase boundary (MPB) compositions (x = 0.16–0.20) (Sasaki et al., 1999; Yoshii et al., 2006) were appropriately modified with ZrO2 (Hussain et al., 2010a), HfO2 (Hussain et al., 2010b), Y2O3 (Do et al., 2010), Nb2O5 (Pham et al., 2010), and Ta2O5 (Do et al., 2011).

The origin of large strain in BNT-based systems has been intensively studied. Based on the temperature-dependent EFIS measurements, Jo et al. (2009) proposed that the large strain is due to the reversible phase transition of a nonpolar (NP) phase to a ferroelectric (FE) phase under electric fields due to their comparable free energies. Later studies on solid solutions of (1 −x)BNT-xBT (abbreviated as BNT-100xBT) systems using synchrotron X-ray diffraction under applied electric fields revealed tetragonal distortion (Daniels et al., 2009, 2010) or coexistence of tetragonal and rhombohedral symmetry (Jo et al., 2011) grown from an unpoled pseudocubic phase.

Similarly, various X-ray diffraction studies have reported electric field–induced phase transitions (EFIPTs) in Mn-doped BNT-5.6BT (Ge et al., 2009), BNT-6BT (Picht et al., 2010), and BNT-20BKT (Royles et al., 2010). Furthermore, in situ transmission electron microscopy (Kling et al., 2010), in situ neutron diffraction (Hinterstein et al., 2010), and in situ volume change measurements (Jo and Rödel, 2011) successfully demonstrated to show reversible EFIPTs in BNT-BT-KNN systems. Neutron diffraction study on BNT-6BT (Simons et al., 2011) further identified an EFIPT that is accompanied by the change in the oxygen octahedral tilting system.

On the other hand, according to our previous studies on B-site-substituted BNKT (Do et al., 2010, 2011; Hussain et al., 2010a, 2010b; Pham et al., 2010), B-site dopants induced a FE to NP phase transition, and subsequent giant strains were observed when the doping level just exceeded the transition point. Interestingly, it was recently found that the FE-NP phase transition occurred when the tolerance factor (t) decreased by doping (Nguyen et al., 2012). The t was first introduced by Goldschmidt (1926) to explain the stability of perovskite structures and expressed as the following equation (1)
where rA, rB, and rO are ionic radii of A- and B-site cations and oxygen, respectively.

Therefore, it seems interesting to clarify whether or not an ABO3-type modifier also induces the FE-NP transition in BNKT ceramics upon decreasing t. To pursue answers for this question, CaZrO3 (CZ) with an ABO3-type perovskite structure is selected as a modifier in this study because its tolerance factor is smaller than that of BNKT. By substituting the reported ionic radii (Shannon, 1976) of Ca2+ (1.34 nm), Zr4+ (0.72 nm), Na+ (1.39 nm), K+ (1.64 nm), Bi3+ (1.36 nm), Ti4+ (0.605 nm), and O2− (1.4 nm) into equation (1), the t values of CZ and BNKT (78/22) are calculated as 0.914 and 0.988, respectively. In addition, it is thought to possibly obtain some clues for understanding the giant strain in Bi-perovskites by comparing the present study on CZ-modified BNKT with previous results on Zr-doped BNKT (Hussain et al., 2010a), which revealed a giant strain of 0.43% and a d33*≈ 614 pm/V. This study reports the effect of CZ modification on the FE, piezoelectric, and EFIS properties of BNKT ceramics and discusses a possible mechanism of FE-NP phase transition in the Bi-perovskite.

sec.title: Experiments
sec.p: BNKT ceramics were prepared by a conventional solid-state reaction method using powders of Bi2O3, TiO2 (99.9%, high-purity chemicals), Na2CO3 (99.9%, high-purity chemicals), K2CO3 (99%, high-purity chemicals), CaCO3 (99.9%, high-purity chemicals), and ZrO2 (99%, CERAC Specialty Inorganics) as starting materials. First, the starting powders were put in the oven at 80°C for 24 h to dry moisture and then weighed according to stoichiometric formulas having the following compositions; (1 –x)BNKT-xCZ (x = 0, 0.01, 0.02, 0.03, 0.04, and 0.06). The powder mixture was ball-milled for 24 h in ethanol with zirconia balls as milling media. The slurries were dried and calcined at 850°C for 2 h. The calcined powder was added with polyvinyl alcohol as a binder and pressed into green disks with a diameter of 12 mm at 100 MPa. Sintering was performed at 1165°C in covered alumina crucibles for 2 h in air.

The crystal structure of sintered samples was characterized by an X-ray diffractometer (XRD; RAD III, Rigaku, Japan). Electrical measurements were carried out after screen-printing Ag paste on both sides of a disk-shaped specimen and firing at 700°C for 30 min. Data on field-dependent polarization for unpoled specimens were acquired at 200 MHz using a modified Sawyer–Tower circuit with a 15-µF capacitor. The dependence of mechanical strain S on an external electric field E was obtained in silicon oil bath using a linear variable differential transducer. The piezoelectric coefficient d33 at zero fields (static d33) was determined using a Berlincourt d33 meter after poling the samples under an electric field of 5 kV/mm for 15 min at 100°C. Dielectric constant and loss tangent of poled specimens were measured using an impedance analyzer (HP 4192A, Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA) attached to a programmable furnace at frequencies of 1, 10, and 100 kHz in a temperature range from room temperature to 550°C. The planar piezoelectric coupling coefficient (kp) and mechanical quality factor (Qm) were determined with an impedance analyzer (HP4194A) on the basis of the resonance and antiresonance methods (ANSI/IEEE Std 176-1987, 1988).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: X-ray diffraction patterns of CZ-substituted BNKT ceramics sintered at 1165°C for 2 h are given in Figure 1. All specimens exhibited a perovskite structure without any trace of a secondary phase. A careful observation indicated that undoped BNKT corresponded to tetragonal symmetry because (002)/(200) reflections at around 46° were concurrently observed. However, the (002)/(200) splitting merged into a pseudocubic (200) reflection as the CZ content increased. Such a change in the crystal structure is very similar to those observed in BNKT modified with Zr (Hussain et al., 2010a) or Hf (Hussain et al., 2010b).

caption.p: X-ray diffraction patterns of CZ-substituted BNKT ceramics as a function of CZ content.

sec.p: Figure 2(a) shows the P-E hysteresis loop of CZ-modified BNKT ceramics with x = 0, 0.01, 0.02, 0.03, 0.04, and 0.06. Pure BNKT ceramics represented a well-saturated loop that is distinct in typical FEs. The remnant polarization (Pr), saturation polarization (Ps), and coercive field (Ec) of undoped BNKT were 35.3 µC/cm2, 44.1 µC/cm2, and 24.0 kV/cm, respectively, which were all in good agreement with previous studies (Hussain et al., 2010a, 2010b). However, as shown in Figure 2(b), the substitution of CZ brought about reductions in the Pr, Ec, and Ps, which became more pronounced with increasing CZ concentration. This indicates that the FE order that was dominant in pure BNKT was disrupted by the addition of CZ.

caption.p: Electric field–induced polarization properties of CZ-substituted BNKT ceramics: (a) P-E hysteresis loops; (b) saturation polarization (Ps), remnant polarization (Pr), and coercive field (Ec) as a function of CZ content.

sec.p: Figure 3(a) shows the bipolar field-induced strain (S-E) hysteresis loop of CZ-substituted BNKT ceramics as a function of CZ content. From the bipolar S-E loops, the poling strain (Spol), maximum strain (Smax), and remnant strain (Srem) were determined as depicted in the loop for x = 0, and the strain values were replotted in Figure 3(b). Undoped BNKT ceramics exhibited typical butterfly-shaped curves with a large poling strain (Spol) of 0.41% and a remnant strain (Srem) of 0.23%. As the CZ content increased up to 0.03 mol, the Srem went down to 0.05% while the Spol maintained at 0.4%. At the same time, the largest normalized strain Smax/Emax over 500 pm/V was obtained. With further increasing the CZ content, both Spol and Smax/Emax rapidly decreased. Composition-dependent S-E loops and various strain properties in this study are very similar to those recently reported on BNKT (80/20) modified with BiZn0.5Ti0.5O3 (Dittmer et al., 2011).

caption.p: Electric field–induced strain properties of CZ-substituted BNKT ceramics: (a) bipolar S-E loops; (b) poling strain (Spol), negative strain (Sneg), remnant strain (Srem), and normalized strain (Smax/Emax) as a function of CZ content.

sec.p: The strain enhancement by CZ substitution was more clearly observed in unipolar S-E loops as shown in Figure 4. The unipolar strain increased with increasing CZ concentration up to x = 0.03 and then decreased. A large strain of 0.36% and corresponding d33* of 617 pm/V were obtained at x = 0.03 under an applied electric field of 60 kV/cm, which was about twice larger than that of pure BNKT. In Figure 5, the high-field d33* that was obtained from the unipolar S-E loop was compared with the small-signal piezoelectric parameters such as the Berlincourt piezoelectric constant (d33), planar piezoelectric coupling coefficient (kp), and electromechanical quality factor (Qm) as a function of CZ content. The d33, kp, and Qm of undoped BNKT were 151, 0.21, and 80, respectively, which agreed well with previously reported values (Hussain et al., 2010a).

caption.p: Unipolar electric field–induced (S-E) hysteresis loops of CZ-substituted BNKT ceramics as a function of CZ content.

Large-signal piezoelectric constant (d33*) that equals the normalized strain (Smax/Emax), small-signal piezoelectric constant (d33), planar piezoelectric coupling coefficient (kp), and electromechanical quality factor (Qm) of CZ-substituted BNKT ceramics as a function of CZ content.

sec.p: It is interesting that abrupt drops in the three piezoelectric parameters were simultaneously observed when 0.03 mol of CZ was doped on BNKT, where the largest d33* of 617 pm/V was obtained. When x is higher than 0.04, specimens showed little piezoelectric responses even after poling treatment at elevated temperatures, indicating a NP state at high CZ levels. These results are also consistent with previous results on Bi-based ceramics that revealed giant strains near the FE-NP phase boundaries when ferroelectricity abruptly disappeared (Do et al., 2011; Hussain et al., 2010a, 2010b; Jo et al., 2009; Zhang et al., 2007).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: As seen in the P-E loops in Figure 3 and the S-E loops in Figure 4, FE BNKT seems to gradually transform into a NP paraelectric phase by CZ modification, which was further evidenced, as shown in Figure 5, by vanishing of small-signal piezoelectric constants d33 and kp when the CZ content was higher than 0.04 mol. Interestingly, a very similar transition behavior was recently reported in BNKT modified with BiZn0.5Ti0.5O3 (Dittmer et al. 2011), which was attributed to relaxor characteristics of the system. In order to clarify the relaxor behavior in our specimens, temperature-dependent dielectric properties were characterized, and the results were given in Figure 6. As shown in the figure, there are two distinct anomalies in the unmodified BNKT (x = 0): the hump at about 130°C that has been known as the depolarization temperature Td and the peak at about 260°C (the maximum dielectric constant temperature Tm). The dielectric spectra were clearly affected by CZ modification, as observed in the figure. The transition at Td gradually became unclear with increasing the CZ content, resulting in strong dielectric dispersions even at room temperature for all CZ-added specimens.

caption.p: Temperature-dependent dielectric constants at 1, 10, and 100 kHz of a poled specimen for different CZ amounts.

sec.p: If we assume that the CZ-modified BNKT ceramics are relaxor–ferroelectrics (RFEs), most of the observed phenomena in this study can be rationalized. In other words, a FE-RFE transition is believed to be induced by CZ modification, which is responsible for the destabilization of the long-range FE order in the lattice, leading to the gradual degradation of both FE (Pr and Ec) and piezoelectric (d33 and kp) properties. Such FE-RFE transitions by chemical modification have been also reported in many solid solution systems such as (1 −x)PbMg1/3Nb2/3O3–xPbTiO3 (Noblanc et al., 1996), SrxBa(1 −x)Nb2O6 (Glass, 1969), BaTi1 −xZrxO3 (Bokov et al., 2007; Shvartsman et al., 2009; Simon et al., 2004), or BaTi1 −xSnxO3 (Lei et al., 2007; Lu et al., 2004; Mueller et al., 2004; Shvartsman et al., 2008). The dielectric relaxation of RFE can be explained by compositional fluctuations or random local electric fields (Kreisel et al., 2001) and stress-induced phase transitions (Uchino and Nomura, 1982) due to randomly distributed cations. Not surprisingly, compounds from an intermediate concentration range were found to exhibit both relaxor and FE properties (Glass, 1969; Noblanc et al., 1996; Salak et al., 2005).

It is interesting to note that the pinching in the P-E loops was observed for specimens with x = 0.02–0.04 in Figure 2(a), which in the past had been interpreted as an indication of antiferroelectricity (Takenaka et al., 1991). The origin of this phenomenon, however, is still under debate. In the case of lead lanthanum zirconate titanate (PLZT), the pinching was reported to be also observed as a consequence of an aging effect (Borchhardt et al., 1980) or accumulated charges at the interphase boundaries (Shur et al., 2005). Instead, the pinching in our specimens is believed to be due to the coexistence of FE and RFE phases that can reversibly transform into each other upon biasing and releasing electric fields, even though further sophisticated studies are required to clarify the mechanism.

At this moment, it seems meaningful to discuss the effect of the tolerance factor on the FE-RFE transition induced by CZ modification, which has been so far believed as a FE-NP phase transition. Such a transition was observed in our precious studies on BNKT modified with B-site dopants such as Zr (Hussain et al., 2010a), Hf (Hussain et al., 2010b), Nb (Pham et al., 2010), and Ta (Do et al., 2011). Interesting is that all these dopants bring about reductions in the tolerance factor as displayed in Figure 7. It can be assumed that the decreased tolerance factor is an important factor in the FE-RFE transition and subsequent giant strains, which are possibly arisen by EFIPT from a macroscopically isotropic RFE to a long-range ordered FE phase under electric fields. The decrease in t is mathematically related with the substitution of either smaller ions on A-sites or larger ions on B-sites. In the case of CZ modification, the ionic radius of Ca2+ (1.34 nm) is smaller than averaged radius of A-site ions (1.40 nm) of undoped BNKT. Instead, Zr4+ is larger than B-site Ti4+ (Shannon, 1976), which seems to predominantly contribute to the destabilization of FE order. It can be easily imagined that the incorporation of a larger ion into the B-site gives rise to detilting of the distorted [BO6] octahedron to enlarge the B-site space.

caption.p: Doping level dependence of the tolerance factor (t) of BNKT for various dopants.

sec.p: The earlier prediction is strongly supported by the fact that CZ modification brings about very similar effects on BNKT as seen in Zr-doped BNKT (Hussain et al., 2010a) in terms of the tolerance factor (Figure 7), crystal structure, ferroelectricity, piezoelectricity, and even EFIS properties. This fact tells that the effect of Zr4+ substitution on B-sites is more pronounced than that of Ca2+ substitution on A-sites because the difference between two modifiers is further Ca2+ substitution on A-sites in addition to Zr doping in the case of CZ modification. Structural and charge inhomogeneities either in A- or B-sites were known as the origin of relaxor behaviors in ABO3 compounds (Davies and Akbas, 2000; Yoshida et al., 1998). The fact that both Zr and CZ gave rise to very similar results indicates that the B-site strain effect plays more dominant role in the FE-RFE transition in BNKT than the A-site inhomogeneity induced by Ca2+ substitution on A-sites.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The effects of CZ modification on the FE, piezoelectric, and EFIS properties of BNKT were examined. The results showed that ABO3-type CZ also brought about a FE to relaxor transition as expected from the fact that CZ addition decreased the tolerance factor like other previous reports on B-site doped BNKT with Zr, Hf, Ta, or Nb. The present result provides more versatility in designing materials in ABO3-BNKT solid solution systems because there are numerous choices in the selection of ABO3 compounds with different tolerance factors. For further rationalization of the tolerance factor–related phase transition and subsequent large strains in Bi-perovskites, it is required to get more experimental evidences for BNKT modified with other ABO3 compounds.

ack.p: The authors thank Dr W. Jo (Technische Universität Darmstadt) for helping S-E loop measurements.

fn.p: This study was financially supported by the Ministry of Knowledge and Economy, Korea (grant no. B0009733).
